transcript.content: Well, here we are again. XFM on a Saturday. Just gone one o'clock Steve, if I'm very much mistaken. But we're not here...
No.
...as such. We're away again. Gallivanting around er, erm, we've got to do the special, sort of, best of again.
Okay
Which we did a few weeks ago. So this is the best of the last three weeks,
(Steve laughs)
Erm, which I think is... I mean, I think it's the best three weeks we've ever had. But I'd like it condensed into two hours. Erm...
Yeah, yeah. Some great music as well in there?
Yeah, there'll be some great music.
Er, interspersed with, with fine chat - that you've already heard.
Yeah.
Well except this bit, this bit's new. We've actually er, out of the kindness of our heart, we've come in, um we've come in last week.
Yeah, yeah.
And we've done a few clips, just cause we felt a bit guilty about shooting off. Um...
Yeah. I mean, I, even now, having heard this link, I'm beginning to wonder if it was worth our time.
Oh dear!
You know, I - I've said in the past to you Rick, that my grandparents - and I love them dearly - but it's like for the last 30 years they've been waiting to die.
I know, yeah
It's like they just sort of, it's like the, you know, the novelty wore off of life
(laugh) Life in the 50s
Yeah, got kind of bored of it. Life - yeah, in the 40s, it was brilliant, all sat around the old Joanna(?) as the bombs fell.
(laughing) Yeah.

Singing, they loved that. The 50s, you know, that was great as well because that was the postwar years. It was, you know, it's a bit tight in the pocket, but it was all right, everyone pulled together. Then the 60s came along all, the crazy music, the funny hair.
Let's, let's stay in bed.

Exactly, they basically stayed in bed. And er, it was one Christmas when erm, my grandmother said to my dad er, "What would you like for Christmas? What do you fancy for Christmas?" And this must have been.. I dunno, 20 years ago.

She said er, what do you er, what do you fancy for Christmas Ron? And he went, "Well, you know, I could do with a nice big kind of warm winter overcoat" She said, "Don't worry about that cause, don't worry about that cause your father will be dead soon. Its alright, you can have his" - meaning my granddad! Well, to be honest with you, my father's still waiting!
(Ricky laughs)
Which is good news. Good news for my grandfather. Less good news for my father he's freezing!
He's freezing. He phones her up - "How is he today?" "He's fine" "Oh, okay... Oh, I'm freezing".
It is ver- such a weird mindset that - I think it's that, to me is what sums up people from that older generation, the forties and fifties, and it
Seems to me that you've got that kind of mindset. It's like you were born in the 30s. And whenever you talk about your childhood it's like, you had like a baked potato to take to school.
No, well I thi- no, I-
And a stick.
The other thing is, I think that it, it, that sort of generation, it seems that the man is dependent on the woman. There's a total dependence.
Absolutely, yeah
If she dies, he's done.
Yes
He's done for. He'll, he'll just pine away. If he dies, she's got 30 years of pottering.
Absolutely, yeah.
D'you know what I mean? And going to like, you know, the youth club and the church club
I know what you mean, yeah.
But yeah, it's sort of like that, it's- it is sad, of course, it's sad for them, but it's sort- not the end of their life.
No, sure
But it sort of is the other way around, I don't know why that is.
Yeah
It's terrible
That's a little melancholy thought for this Christmas time
I know, I've really brought it - YOU brought it down. You've brought it down. I wanted to - this isn't a nice show at all. This is terrible.
Well I didn't really wanna make it -
We're gonna have people just killing themselves. What?
Well, I didn't really want to make it a Christmassy type show. Cause I know you don't, you don't really like it.
Oh, he's done it again! What, we did Christmas once, didn't like it?
No, it- me dad always said
Alright, steady on.
Dad said Christmas morning was for like, you know, for me. So he used to stay in bed. So he, he never -
That's brilliant. That's a great thing to say innit? Yeah, yeah. Christmas is always for you. Run wild, do what you want, just don't bother me.
So I'm going to Honolulu for two weeks
(laught) That's great. "Dad, it's Christmas." "Do I have to do anything?" "No."
So me mam used to get up because she used to like to see me face light up, you know, when I opened the presents
(muttering)Must have give him fireworks
And then, erm...
(Steve and Ricky laugh)
Then I'd have to go to me bedroom from about six o'clock onwards, because like me mam and dad were into having big christmas parties and I wasn't like old enough to go.
Right.
So they'd say "Right. You know, you've had your fun, now you go up to your bedroom- stay in there."
Ricky sniggers
Really?

Yeah, I remember one year right, I got got a train set - that's what I wanted - right? Brilliant, err- playing with it all day and I thought "I don't mind about the party, I'm happy staying up here playing with this". Brother comes in, he's had a few. He's going "Here you are give us a go on your train set".
How old is he?
He's a bit older than me. So he might have been like, err- let's see...
Well, let him be 18.
Yeah, probably about 18, 19... summat like that.
And how old were you?
I was, well, I had a train set so... I dunno about--

Summat like that. Right, so err- so I'm playing on that, loving it and stuff and then he comes in and goes "oh give us a go". He turns the transformer up to like fourteen, it went really fast for about five seconds. Broke it... and then he went back downstairs.
Wow.
So christmas- I hadn't even got me christmas err--
Sounds like the err- conservative government with err- British Rail.
Satire that is.
Sat- Rick I just thought that then! It's satire! If there's any satirical shows listening or--
It doesn't work- it doesn't work in any way because there's- the analogy falls down apart from there being a train.
No, think it through though. British Rail is trains--
Yeah.
And the government broke the trains in many- well they didn't break them like not officially breaking them but they kind of--
Oh, yeah it does work, it's perfect.
(laughing) Ohh, I'm very pleased with that.
And I can't- and- no one's asked him to be on Have I Got News For You?
It weird isn't it? Because it is strange that--
Yeah!
When you've got satirical mind that- that's as quick as that.
Yeah... And it- err- broke your little train set so what did you do?
I just like watched telly and had some sausages.
I bet you were happy with that though weren't you?
Well, it's a bit annoying though innit when your main present of the year has been broke.
And it did ever get fixed.
No, that was it- that was it, put away--
I'm intrigued why your parents wouldn't let you come and join in the festive fun, was it like really debauch down there? Was it like eggnog everywhere?
Nah--
Well no, but I mean- that's fair enough. 6 is a little bit early, but I just think, you know, if your- your kid- you know, he had his fun put him to bed- put him to bed at 8 maybe.
You think so? On christmas day? I thought that was a day for family?
Well not if there's a party going on.
Well don't have the party on christmas day, that's my point.
Well that's- that's another option.
Yeah... your parents are weird aren't they? They're a strange breed.

Well, I think that was the year, right, I err- you're talking about buying presents and stuff. I think I did treat me mam to- I didn't buy me dad anything, I think that was like when I got a bit older I used to get me dad something cause he wasn't that bothered anyway.
No.
No...
So err- got me mam err- there was a cheap shop-
(chuckling) Of course!
Thank god for that.
Err- called Snips, alright?
Ricky and Steve chuckle
So I went in there and I thought "let's see what I can get her." and remember err- Victoria Plum?
I don't think so.
Well it's like a fairy character, right?
Right.
And me mams into gnomes and stuff, right? So... I thought "right..."--
Ricky sniggers
She must be pleased with you then!
Ricky cackles
Ahh Victoria Plum, I was thinking "is that one of the neighbours? Is it- is it like a brandy liqueur??"
Do you remember Victoria Plum?
Victoria Plum?
Victoria Plum, yeah, it's like a little fictional sort of character.
Ok.
So err- so I saw it and I thought "yeah she'll love that", right? So I did me paper round, saved up for two weeks right.
Awww.

Got that sorted, went to snips, bought the err- Victoria Plum. Next day I'm in town with her, right? So I think "Ahh I know what I'll do", I said "Come- come in here a minute", right? Err- so we go in and we're looking around and I tested her, right? I went "look at that there, that's alright innit?" and she goes "Oh it's bloody awful."
Steve inhales sharply and laughs
Aww Karl. Aw Karl, I just- I- I- oh god...
So then christmas day comes and I said "don't bother opening it" and she says "no, no, why??" and I said--
Oh no! Why did you still give it to her??
So- well it was too late, I'd already bought it.
Aw Karl.

So she opened it and I was like "ugh" and she said "Oh that's nice" and I said "Why are you saying that? the other day you were saying it's bloody awful!" she said "Oh no, I thought you're pointing at something else."
Ohhhhh nooo!
So that's why I don't get anyone anything anymore.
(cackling) Oh god! Play a record! Oh god! Oh!
Athlete - You've Got the Style
Kings of Leon - Molly's Chambers
XFM 104.9, We're not here. Errm- this next clip is one of my favourite clips. Look, it needs no introduction, here it is.
Something err-
Steve laughs
Something else we're giving away--
Go on.
The Shining.
It's more throwing away innit?
Once again--
Is it on video?
Once again it's on VHS...
Just because you buy out of your own money, Karl. Stop being so mean!
And I want to watch it tonight because its one of those films that errm.
(laughing) So you're going to watch this video and then you're going to send it to someone as a prize?
Yeah, its one of them films that--
Sorry, you just said yes to that without blinking!
Well yeah. You don't think like Les Dennis doesn't have a quick go in the car, on Family Fortunes, before he gives that away?
Ricky cackles
It costs £5.99
(mumbling) Has a go at those his and her towel racks.
It costs £5.99 Karl.
Ok, this is Karl in in the classic, The Shining.
And what's the question?
Well we might ask that afterwards.
Ok then.
"The Shining" begins.
Alright? Still err- still trying to write the err- the book then?
Yes.
Good... funny someone told me the other day, weird thing about typewriters: the top row of letters, the longest word you can write is "typewriter". Right? I'll just- just show you- just-
Typewriter keys being pressed
That's weird innit? It's just- the typewriter being... you're not- you're not in the mood are you? You're just gonna- you're in one of those grouchy moods again that you get into when you're writing.
I'm not being grouchy, I just want to finish my work.
Yeah just- just- just being a bit funny, being a bit offhand and that.
Jack clears his throat
Let me explain something to you.
Go on.
Whenever you come in here and interrupt me you're breaking my concentration, you're distracting me and it will then take me time to get back to where I was. Understand?
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
We'll be talking about bonobos, you're excited about that.
Yeah, yeah.
That's uh, coming up in uhh, Monkey News?
Uhhhh... No I think it's a bit of a, Monkey Bonus.
Ricky and Steve laugh
That was great. That was very very funny indeed.
What a wonderful clip that was.
I enjoyed it.
D'you remember that?
I- yeah.
Yeah, well, it was only a coupl- few weeks ago, wasn't it really, I mean...
I think it was last week.
We'd have to have very, very bad memories not to remember that hilarious... clip. I'd like to hear that again maybe in a couple of week's time when I'm away.
Steve laughs
Yes! Absolutely.
I- is- this embarrassing, innit?
Mhm.
And we, you know. But you know the good thing is, o-on telly I feel a bit guilty about putting out shoddy rubbish because I'm getting paid an awful lot.
Yes.
But here... you know, I- I don't give a s***! They can bleep that.
They will do, they will do.
White Stripes - Dead Leaves And The Dirty Ground
David Bowie - Lady Stardust
Bit of David Bowie. When's that ever hurt anyone Steve?
Never.
Lady Stardust off Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars, on Xfm 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington is in the middle of educating me. 'Colon then, educate me'.
Did I tell you the time...
Ricky sniggers
When, uh, the doctor said I was going to die?
Alright, keep talking
Right, ages ago, umm, must have been about fifteen, right? And, uhh

At lunch time, there was this... we used to have a choice of stuff to do at lunch time, right? Used to have, umm, like a- like a burger place, that had an arcade machine in it, right? So we used to go there, have a play on that and have a burger. Or, there was this bakers, right, that me Mam worked at. And, uh, did great cakes and stuff, right. So, um,

She used to like bring some home and that, but she couldn't always bring them home every night because, you know, the-they'd cost money and she used to get 'em for free, and they used to say: they'd rather chuck them away than give 'em to the staff because there's a chance that the cream might be off.
Right.
Right? So they used to chuck 'em round the back.
Ricky sighs
So I used to go round the back with me mate. And eat a load.
Brilliant. Scavengi- eating out of bins.
Steve chuckles
Nah it was really- it wasn't out of bins, they were still in trays but they just stacked them up near the bins, right? So this got out, I mean it used to be chocka!
Once the school found out, everybody used to go there and it'd be like, well 'ave a cake...
The headmaster crawling through 'em.
Ricky laughs
Yeah.
Fighting the kids off.
Ricky laughs more
Right, so I'd like, y'know, you just eat, I dunno six jam doughnuts or something, and then you'd spend your dinner money on the arcade machine.
Brilliant.
Right? So it was a good- good afternoon really, right. So, you'd do that and, this one day I must have had, six or seven, uh, jam doughnuts, few congress tarts, uh...
Ricky and Steve laugh
What's a congress tart?
Just, I love 'em, It's me fav- I can't get 'em in London,
Right? So, I'd have some of them-
Ricky laughs
Uhh, and I think maybe-
Uh, if anyone can get a congress tart, um, for Karl in London, please let him know.
So anyway, this day, that was just a normal day, d'you know what I mean you'd, once or twice a week you'd have a load of cake.
In your life, yeah.
So anyway-
Yeah, a normal day in your life, and were the frog boys there, with the- with the, webbed hands and the big heads?
So...
And the horse in the settee, uh, ya.
But the day after one of these days I had really bad cramp in me belly, right?
Oh dear.
I was like, in agony, could hardly walk, so I said to me Mam: "Hahh
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
That is a blinding record and before that Rick, what did you make of those adverts, they were great weren't they...
I like them, yeah, I'm gonna buy all them products on the way home.
...and that's endorsed by Ricky Gervais. He's won awards. Rick, d'you remember this, this was a hilarious moment.
No.
No you'll remember this, when you hear it.
Go on.
It was when Karl said something that was basically, well, I think for a lot of people, it sounded like a lot of old bollocks.
Ricky laughs.
What have we got now?
Right, so we- we're looking to animals that we're getting rid of. I've spoken to someone about snails, I've spoke to someone about jellyfish. And that. And, uh...
Ricky sniggers
Looking at cockroaches today.
She is an expert? She's just not- not just some random person?
No, she works in a museum. Where- a good Museum, I said I'd give it a plug. It's the one near Knightsbridge, it's got dinosaurs and that in it, it's worth seeing. And this is her-
What? Natural history museum?
Yep. So, uh...
Ricky and Steve snigger
He's not sure. He's not sure.
Ricky laughs
Go ahead.
This is what happened.
Do We Need 'Em Intro
Now, what I'll do, I'll tell you... as much as- as I know, and then you can fill me in, if I'm right or wrong. And then, at the end of it, we'll get to the bottom of whether we need them or not.
Okay.
All right, so, uh, first of all, uh, the first thing that I c- that I found out is that, uhm... that they have eigh- 18 knees.
Ah... that's not exactly possible. They're insects. So they have six legs.
Yeah.
And a knee is usually the junction between femur and tibia, that sort of classic human knee, and every other animal knee. So, with six legs, it can only have six knees.
Could somebody, sort of, got mistaken for... seeing one that was a bit double-jointed. Cover tracks.
I-I think you're grasping at straws or something-
All right, well uh- well we might have to come back to that one then. They can hold their breath for 40 minutes.
Well, they don't do that... because they don't breathe in the same way as us. They breathe through little spiracles, holes down they- the side of the body. So... um... no.
If it-
They're not a very apt simile, because the- the method of breathing is so different.
What do you mean?

Because insects have a... a totally different system, they don't have lungs in the way that we do. Just breathing through one part of the body. They're actually breathing through every segment of the body, all of the time.
So even though they've got their mouth shut, they might be having a sly-
The mouth has nothing to do with breathing.
So just-
Only feeding.
So, you see, maybe that's... where someone's gone wrong. Someone's got hold of one and, sort of... taped its mouth up or something. And...
Thought it was-
Got bored after 40 minutes. And said well we'll call it right-
Again that sounds a pretty unkind thing to do to an insect, even a cockroach.
Yeah but it's all-
Can't do that.
Yeah, but-
No. Pretty unkind thing to do anything- to anything, even a cockroach.
Something else I found out.
Yeah...?
They can live for a week without an 'ead.
Well, that's true, if they don't bleed to death in the process.
But the weird thing is, when I told you that they had 18 knees, you seemed a bit sort of... like, "don't- don't talk ridiculous," but then we're talking about an animal that can live without an 'ead.
Uh...
So- so there's a little bit of truth in that one, yeah?
Yes...
Why, when it was invented, has it got that facility?

Say if someone said to humans: "we could do that with humans. And, you know, if you lose your head in some... accident, it gives you a bit of time to sort of go back to you- to your family, and maybe write them-
Judith sniggers.
Write them a note. You wont be able to have a chat with them, but write a note saying: "it was me own fault," and, uh, "it was nice knowing you." Ah-
Oh, well, it would be a useful facility, I agree. But cockroaches are great survivors. I mean, they've been around for over 300 million years. They're one of the most primitive insects...
Alright. Well I've also, um- is it true that they do a lot of resting? Apparently they can, sort of, rest. For 75% of the time.
Rest...
Yeah. They just- just sit about. Doing nothing.
It's probably true of a vast proportion of- of the world's fauna.
I mean maybe- maybe the 25% that they are workin' they're really giving it some, so it might make up-

And they're probably searching out food and, uh... yeah. They can slow down considerably. You can chill insects in the fridge and they'll become... very, very quiet. You might think they're dead, but they're-
Yeah but I'm sure, you know, if- if we were sat in a fridge. We- you know, we'd go a bit quiet, wouldn't we? You know.
I... well you might not know much about it, of course.
Yeah, but...
You're not quite reading the- the right... sources.
Well, I've been using the internet.
I'm sure there are many useful sources that you could find there, but some of those seem to have been a little, um, misleading to you.
So... so you don't agree with... with... a lot of what I've told you there...
No.
So, cockroaches... can we get rid of them?
No.
So we're keeping them then?
I would say so, yes.
Do We Need 'Em Outro

I think we should get her on more often, because... she sounds like she'd be a bit of an ally, really. 'Cause she knew, immediately, that you were talking nonsense. She even said "I think you should be more concerned about your sources," which I've been trying to tell you for a year. A'ight? The fact- I mean... I'm- "18 knees." Where did you get that from?
It was, uh... it was on the internet.
Uh- they can "hold their breath" for fourty minutes.
Steve giggles
I mean... I don't know what- I don't know what you read and take on.
Mad world though, innit.
Steve laughs.
Ricky laughs.
The Cure - I Will Always Love You
Missy Elliot - Gossip Folks (Fat Boy Slim Radio Edit)
Hello there.

Karl is actually in a little booth. We're not in the studio, you see, this is pre-recorded. We recorded this last week, cos we're away, and this is sort of like the 'best of.' Best of the last three weeks, since the last time we were away when we put out the 'best of'...
Okay, what’s the next one, what’s the next Educating Ricky?
Well, I don’t know uh… see, like I say, I was loo—looking around and there’s stuff that… is interesting… right, I was looking on the Web…
But there’s no point.
Well, it’s just that I found one about, uh…
What’s the point?
…about a lad who, uh, eight years old…
Yeah.
…b—but he’s still breast-fed.
Ricky chuckles
Steve bursts out laughing
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Her Brain?

And this is what's good about the internet. I went straight from that and there was a subject about brains and, do you know, that Russell Crow, when he dies is giving his brain to charity or something. Some sort of... some people who can do stuff with it.
She gave hers to Pot Noodle.
Ricky Laughs
Vesta...  Eurgh, boiling a skill.
That's the sort of stuff. Yeah
That's.. It's not true
It's not true, Karl. Just Urban myths, someone made up.
Yeah
For a laugh
They're just too convenient Urban myths

Everyone says. You can tell an urban myths not true, because it's always: this happened to a mate of mine and when you say 'what happened then?' They go: 'Dunno, that was it' Was it? Was that it was it? Someone boiled their brain and that was it? There was no more story.
Where there any dates? Locations? Times?
I think it was in Belgium
There's that- there's that- there's that one.
Ricky Laughs
There's that one, that a bloke, right? Was going to get a phone call at 4 o'clock to find out if his business was, you know, okay, right?

And if he didn't get the phone call, he knew he was um broke, destitute. So at dead on four o'clock, the phone didn't ring. So he went up to the- the roof his office and he jumped off commit suicide, and as he was passing his window, the phone was ringing.
Oh no!
Ricky and Steve burst out laughing
Karl, it didn't happen.
It didn't happen!
Think it through
Think it through. Who told that story? Who told that story? As he hit the pavement at a hundred and twenty miles an hour
He's the only person who could have known those, that series of incidents...
Also why didn't he wait?
...and he's dead
As his life's at stake, why didn't he wait 'til 5 past. Actually, I'm gonna give it five minutes just in case
Just in case the lines are busy
Yeah. And what sort of bloke goes: "I'll call you at four, okay, if your business is -"
Well call me anyway?
"Nope, no. If I don't call at exactly four, then you need to commit suicide."
Commit suicide?
"I would, because if I don't call at four, eurgh, that's the end of it"
Well call me anyway?
"No, that's not the way I work"
Why can't you just call me and tell me either way?
"Well, I'm telling you how I do it"
"If you're bust I don't call."
Can't you just call to verify it, in case something goes wrong? What if it's engaged?
"It won't be engaged. Just commit suicide at four, please."

It didn't happen, Karl. Have you heard the other one, right? A bloke, right. He's on a train station and uh- I'll tell you how I heard it. He's- he's waiting for- at Crewe station, wherever, and he shits himself, as you do. And so he goes: oh my train's in five minutes.
So he runs across to Millets, and goes quick, Levi's, 36. The bloke just puts it in a bag. He runs onto the train, he goes into the toilet, takes his trousers and pants off.
His soiled, trousers and pants
Yes. Throws them out of the window. I'll won't be needing those again. Cleans himself off, open the bag. It's a jacket!
Ohhhh
NO IT DIDN'T HAPPEN KARL
At what point did he go into a go-go- Quick, Levi's 36, and the bloke went:
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

synopsis.description: Intro once again copy pasted from Pilkipedia. (http://www.pilkipedia.co.uk/wiki/index.php?title=01_March_2003/Transcript#They_Can_Hold_Their_Breath_For_Forty_Minutes)
Re-run of Do We Need 'Em - Cockroaches. Name changed to Judith as explained in previous contribution from this episode.

I use the name "Judith" for the guest despite Karl introducing her as Jessica. The trivia section of the Pilkipedia article for the original episode of Do We Need 'Em explains why (http://www.pilkipedia.co.uk/wiki/index.php?title=18_January_2003#Trivia)

I copy pasted these lines from the Pilkipedia transcript (http://www.pilkipedia.co.uk/wiki/index.php?title=01_March_2003/Transcript#They_Can_Hold_Their_Breath_For_Forty_Minutes) and from the Scrimpton copy of the Classic Link (https://scrimpton.com/ep/ep-xfm-S2E12#pos-89800) just to keep things a bit more consistent and to save time.
